huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: This unit is a General Season hunt unit and is not managed to be a trophy unit however, every year a few nice bucks are taken. The unit population has been increasing over the past few years, along with the buck to doe ratio. Hunters should be aware of the Ute Tribal Lands and learn the boundaries. Public hunting is not permitted on Tribal Lands. There are 3 CWMUs on this unit, which general season permits are not permitted. A list of all CWMUs is available on the UDWR webpage: http://wildlife.utah.gov/maps/public/list_cwmus.php
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS: Flash floods and lightning strikes are very likely during inclement weather, make sure to watch the sky and plan accordingly.  Always let somebody know where you'll be, and when you expect to be back.  Cell phone service is somewhat limited throughout the unit.  Black bears are regularly seen on the Abajos.  Keep a clean camp and make sure to place all food and garbage in locations that bears cannot get into.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season.  Be prepared for rain, lightening, snow, wind and heat.  It is quite common on clear mornings for clouds to build through the morning and have thunderstorms in the afternoon.  Be very cautious of lightening while hunting on high ridges and flash floods in the canyon bottoms.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 50~13500~12400~15–17~19~~~~~~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
Migration Patterns: The Mule deer on the Abajos typically leave the higher elevations during mid to late fall and head for the winter range at lower elevations. Winter range occurs in all directions from the mountain range. In mid to late spring, the deer tend to follow the green-up of grasses/forbs and head back to higher elevations.

Scouting Tips: Start scouting in late July early August, most deer will be up high and typically seen feeding in large meadows early in the mornings and just before dark. The deer may not be in the same place during the any weapon hunt, but early scouting will give you an idea of what kind of bucks are on the unit. Spend some time before your hunt to learn the roads and access points. Typically, bucks will be in bachelor groups from early to late summer. Once the rut starts, bucks will be found with and around does. Yearling bucks can be found year-round with does, or in bachelor groups.

Mule deer rut: The mule deer rut usually runs from mid Nov.-mid Dec. so it does not affect these hunts.

Recommended areas for the San Juan, Abajo subunit:
Abajo Mountain- Muzzleloader hunters may find bucks in the high country, but should also focus on mid elevations. Look for oak-brush stands or sagebrush parks, surrounded by pinyon/juniper communities.

huntMaster.NOTES:
Baiting big game for the purposes of hunting is now illegal in Utah.
Click here for more information.

The use of all trail cameras (including both non-handheld transmitting and non-transmitting devices) in the harvest or to aid in the harvest of big game is prohibited between July 31 and Dec. 31. Click here for more information.
huntMaster.HARVEST_REPORTING: Voluntary: The DWR conducts random surveys for all general season hunts. You may be contacted via phone to participate in this survey.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Public, Private and Tribal Lands.  The public lands are primarily US Forest Service lands managed by the Manti-La Sal National Forest and The Bureau of Land Management(BLM) managed out of the Monticello and Moab Field Offices.  This unit also includes Ute Tribal lands that are closed to non-tribal members The Tribal lands are mostly in the South Cottonwood area of the unit in the lower canyons. The private lands are primarily on the South and Southeast portions of the unit, on and near agricultural lands. There are three CWMU's on the unit (Spring Creek/Dodge, Deer Haven and Summit Point).
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
All Campgrounds on this subunit are managed by the US Forest Service, Utah State Institutional Trust Lands and the Bureau of Land Management. Camping outside of official campgrounds is also permitted on most of the Forest. Please direct all questions regarding campground availability and other camping questions to the US Forest Service, SITLA or the BLM. Maps and camping regulations are available on their websites.
USFS: http://www.fs.usda.gov/mantilasal
SITLA: http://trustlands.utah.gov/business-groups/surface/recreational-use-of-trust-lands/
BLM: http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/prog/recreation_home/activities/camping.html
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: Shay Mountain, Blue Crk. Indian Crk.
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Blanding, Bluff, La Sal, Moab.
huntBoundaryInfos.COUNTY_ROAD_INFO:
San Juan County: http://www.utahscanyoncountry.com/index.html
Grand County: http://www.grandcountyutah.net/
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS:
Most roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the US Forest Service, Utah State Institutional Trust Lands and the Bureau of Land Management and are covered on their Travel Management Plans. Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the US Forest Service, SITLA or the BLM.
USFS: http://www.fs.usda.gov/mantilasal
SITLA: http://trustlands.utah.gov/business-groups/surface/recreational-use-of-trust-lands/
BLM: http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/prog/recreation_home/activities/ohv_riding.html
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: There are several areas of private land on this subunit, including 3 CWMU’s (Spring Creek, Dodge, Deer Haven and Summit Point). Hunters must receive written permission before hunting private lands. There is also Native American (Ute tribe) land on the Southern portion of the subunit, mostly in canyon bottoms.  Be sure to pay attention to where you are, and study maps before your hunt, please respect ALL posted lands.  San Juan General Season deer permits are not valid on deer CWMU’s or Native American lands.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Grand and San Juan counties—Boundary begins at US-163 and South Cottonwood Creek (near Bluff); north along this creek to Allen Canyon; north along this canyon bottom to Chippean Canyon; north along this canyon bottom to Deep Canyon; north along this canyon bottom to Mule Canyon; north along this canyon bottom to the Big Causeway; north from the Big Causeway to Trough Canyon; north along this canyon bottom to North Cottonwood Creek; north along this creek to Indian Creek; north along this creek to the Colorado River; north along this river to Kane Springs Creek; southeast along this creek to Hatch Wash; southeast along this wash to US-191; south on US-191 to Big Indian road; east on this road to Lisbon Valley road; southeast on this road to Island Mesa road; east on this road to the Utah-Colorado state line; south on this line to the Navajo Indian Reservation boundary; west and south along this boundary to the San Juan River; west along this river to US-163 at Mexican Hat; east on US-163 to South Cottonwood Creek. EXCLUDES ALL NATIVE AMERICAN TRUST LANDS WITHIN THIS BOUNDARY. EXCLUDES ALL NATIONAL PARKS. Excludes all CWMUs. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Blanding, Bluff, La Sal, Moab. Boundary questions? Call the Price office, 435-613-3700.
